    Synthesis and Biological Characterization of Cyclic Disulfide-Containing Peptide Analogs of the Multifunctional Opioid/Neuropeptide FF Receptor Agonists That Produce Long-Lasting and Nontolerant Antinociception

    • Mengna Zhang
      Mengna Zhang

    SUBJECTS:
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Central nervous system,
    • Monomers,
    • Plasma,
    • Receptors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    In a previously described chimeric peptide, we reported that the multifunctional opioid/neuropeptide FF (NPFF) receptor agonist 0 (BN-9) produced antinociception for 1.5 h after supraspinal administration. Herein, four cyclic disulfide analogs containing l- and/or d-type cysteine at positions 2 and 5 were synthesized. The cyclized analogs and their linear counterparts behaved as multifunctional agonists at both opioid and NPFF receptors in vitro and produced potent analgesia without tolerance development. In comparison to 0, cyclized peptide 6 exhibited sevenfold more potent μ-opioid receptor agonistic activity in vitro. Interestingly, the cyclized analog 6 possessed an improved stability in the brain and an increased blood–brain barrier permeability compared to the parent peptide 0 and produced more potent analgesia after supraspinal or subcutaneous administration with improved duration of action of 4 h. In addition, antinociceptive tolerance of analog 6 was greatly reduced after subcutaneous injection compared to fentanyl, as was the rewarding effect, withdrawal reaction, and gastrointestinal inhibition.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    It is well-known that classical opioid analgesics including morphine and fentanyl effectively activate the μ-opioid receptor, which is most responsible for their desired antinociception and undesired side effects, such as constipation, respiratory depression, tolerance, and addiction.(1−4) Thus, the development of novel opioid drugs lacking side effects is one of the major goals in pain research. Recently, a new generation of opioid analgesics that simultaneously target opioid receptors and some other receptors with modulatory effects on opioid activities has been developed.(5−7) For example, the uses of the nociceptin/orphanin FQ receptor (ant)agonists, neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor (ant)agonists, cannabinoid-1 receptor antagonists, or cholecystokinin type 2 receptor antagonists, are combined with opioids.(8−11) Notably, the Ko group has reported that a series of bifunctional nociceptin and μ-opioid receptor agonists (BU08028, AT-121, and BU10038) produced potent antinociception without opioid-like side effects in nonhuman primates, such as abuse liability and respiratory depression.(12−15)
    Neuropeptide FF (NPFF) is an endogenous opioid-modulating peptide and plays opioid-modulating roles in antinociception, tolerance, and addition.(16−18) In our previous studies, several multifunctional peptides with opioid/neuropeptide FF receptor agonistic activities, such as EN-9, BN-9 (analog 0), and DN-9, were characterized that could produce nontolerant antinociception.(19−21) Our data showed that 0 simultaneously activated opioid and NPFF receptors and produced potent nontolerance-forming antinociception for 1.5 h after central or peripheral injection.(20,22) However, recent pharmacological characterization has shown that 0 could not cross the blood–brain barrier (BBB).(22) In carrageenan-induced hindpaw inflammation model, the antiallodynic potency of BN-9 after central administration was more potent than that of BN-9 given systemically.(23) In fact, the therapeutics of opioid peptides are often limited due to their low BBB permeabilities and poor resistances to proteolytic degradation.
    The advances in medicinal chemistry have shown that the cyclizations of linear peptides improve their potencies, receptor selectivities, bioavailabilities, BBB permeabilities, and biodistributions by limiting their conformational flexibilities and increasing their lipophilicities.(24−27) Compared to their linear parents, cyclic analogs exhibit better defined conformations. Thus, the cyclic peptide analogs can pay lower entropy when binding to target receptors and provide significant insights into a preferred conformation for receptor interaction. In the past years, cyclic constraints of opioid peptides had been used to improve their efficacies, binding affinities, biostabilities, and receptor selectivities.(28) The successful examples were the δ-opioid receptor selective agonists DPDPE and JOM-13, the μ-opioid receptor selective ligands JOM-6, CTAP, and CTOP, and the κ-opioid receptor selective antagonist zyklophin.(29−33) Importantly, the cyclic analogs of EM-1 exhibited improved the half-life up to 27-fold relative to the parent peptide EM-1 (a half-life of 5.6 min) in human plasma.(34) Recently, cyclization modification was also applied to the bifunctional opioid peptide TY027, and its cyclic analog TY038 maintained opioid receptor agonistic and NK1 receptor antagonistic activities and had an improved stability with a half-life of more than 24 h in rat plasma.(9) To improve bioavailability, BBB permeability, and in vivo efficacy of 0, we expanded our original sequence and designed four cyclic disulfide analogs and their linear counterparts. Cysteine was used to replace the positions of d-Ala2 and Gln5 of peptide 0 (analog 5), which was tolerant of substitution with other amino acids in our recent study.(21) In addition, to further explore the stereochemical features of the Cys residue in positions 2 and 5 of analog 5, d-Cys was also used to replace the Cys2 or/and Cys5 position (analogs 6–8). The corresponding linear peptides (analogs 1–4) of these four cyclic disulfide analogs of 0 were used as reference compounds. Our data showed that these cyclic disulfide analogs and their corresponding linear peptides functioned as multifunctional agonists for μ-, δ-, κ-opioid, NPFF1, and NPFF2 receptors in vitro. In addition, the antinociceptive activities and side effects of these analogs were evaluated and compared to 0. Strikingly, cyclized peptide 6 possessed an improved stability in the brain and an increased BBB permeability compared to the parent peptide 0 and produced more potent and nontolerance-forming analgesia with improved duration of action of 4 h. In addition, subcutaneous (s.c.) injection of analog 6 had a limited rewarding effect, withdrawal reaction, and gastrointestinal inhibition in comparison to fentanyl.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis

    In our work, all analogs were designed with the multifunctional peptide 0 as the template molecule. Previous studies have shown that the peptide 0 possessed potent antinociceptive activities with reduced side effects.(20,22) To further optimize this multifunctional peptide, we designed and synthesized four cyclic analogs with disulfides linkage at positions 2 and 5 since advantages of the cyclic disulfide linkage have been shown to improve bioavailabilities and membrane permeabilities of opioid peptides.(34) In this work, the corresponding linear peptides of these four cyclic disulfide analogs of 0 were used as reference compounds. The peptide sequences of the synthesized analogs of 0 are presented in Table 1.
    Table 1. Structures of Synthesized Multifunctional Peptide Analogs in the Present Study
    compd.namesabbreviated namessequences
    0 BN-9Tyr-d-Ala-Gly-Phe-Gln-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    1OFP001[Cys2, Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-Cys-Gly-Phe-Cys-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    2OFP002[d-Cys2, Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-d-Cys-Gly-Phe-Cys-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    3OFP003[Cys2, d-Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-Cys-Gly-Phe-d-Cys-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    4OFP004[d-Cys2, d-Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-d-Cys-Gly-Phe-d-Cys-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    5OFP005c[Cys2, Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-c[2,5][Cys-Gly-Phe-Cys]-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    6OFP006c[d-Cys2, Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-c[2,5][d-Cys-Gly-Phe-Cys]-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    7OFP007c[Cys2, d-Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-c[2,5][Cys-Gly-Phe-d-Cys]-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    8OFP008c[d-Cys2, d-Cys5]-BN-9Tyr-c[2,5][d-Cys-Gly-Phe-d-Cys]-Pro-Gln-Arg-Phe-NH2
    To examine the effects of Cys/d-Cys substitutions and cyclizations at positions 2 and 5 of peptide 0, linear peptides (analogs 1–4) and their corresponding cyclic analogs (analogs 5–8) were synthesized by Fmoc solid-phase methods. Cyclizations of these cyclic peptides were obtained by the oxidations of the thiols groups of the Cys or/and d-Cys residues with a solution of iodine in dimethylformamide (DMF). Purification was performed by semipreparative reversed-phase high pressure liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC). Purity analysis was then performed by analytical RP-HPLC. Two gradients, acetonitrile from 10 to 80 and 10 to 100% in 30 min, were used for purity analysis, respectively. As shown in Table 2, the purities of these peptides used in all experiments were ≥95%, which was identified by analytical RP-HPLC. The detailed results of mass spectrometry (ESI-Q-TOF maXis-4G, Bruker Daltonics, Germany) and melting points (mp) of these analogs are provided in Table 2.
    Table 2. Analytical Data for Multifunctional Peptide Analogs
      RP-HPLC 10–80% in 30 minRP-HPLC 10–100% in 30 minMD-TOF-MS [M + H]+ 
    compd.namestRa (min)purityb (%)tRa (min)purityb (%)calcdfoundmp (°C)
    1OFP00115.497.413.798.61119.341119.49150–152
    2OFP00215.797.213.799.01119.341119.49149–151
    3OFP00316.495.116.496.11119.341119.49144–146
    4OFP00416.799.516.395.71119.341119.49159–161
    5OFP00517.895.516.297.41117.341117.50193–195
    6OFP00618.295.816.1100.01117.341117.46205–207
    7OFP00716.395.413.995.61117.341117.48181–183
    8OFP00814.696.313.796.71117.341117.47199–201
    a

    tR with XBridge BEH 130 Prep C18 (4.6 mm × 250 mm, 5 μm). The gradients 10–80 and 10–100% indicate solvent gradients of CH3CN in water from 10 to 80% in 30 min and from 10 to 100% in 30 min, respectively.

    b

    Purity determination based on analytical RP-HPLC.

    Biological Results

    In Vitro Cyclic Adenosine Monophosphate Functional Activities

    The abilities of these new analogs of peptide 0 in activating G-protein-coupled opioid and NPFF receptors were evaluated using cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) functional assay in HEK-293A cells, which stably express opioid or NPFF receptors. The results were expressed as the median effective concentration (EC50) and the maximal inhibition of cAMP accumulation (Emax) of these analogs in forskolin-stimulated cAMP assay.
    The results of functional activities of these analogs at opioid receptors are shown in Table 3. All analogs concentration dependently exhibited opioid agonistic activities in cells stably expressing μ-, δ-, or κ-opioid receptors. In cells expressing the μ- or δ-opioid receptor, the opioid agonistic activities of most of the analogs were not significantly affected by Cys/d-Cys substitutions and cyclizations at positions 2 and 5 of peptide 0. These results were consistent with our recent structure–activity relationship studies that the single substitution of position 2 or 5 of peptide 0 with other amino acids had no significant effects on the agonistic activities at μ- and δ-opioid receptors.(21) However, both the linear peptide 1 and its corresponding cyclic analog 5 showed a slight loss of μ-opioid receptor agonistic activity. In addition, the cyclic analog 7 showed a lower potency for μ-opioid receptor agonistic activity as compared to its corresponding linear analog 3 or the parent peptide 0.(20) Notably, the cyclic analog 6 possessed the highest potencies at μ- and δ-opioid receptors among these analogs. Compared to the parent peptide 0, the μ- and δ-opioid receptor agonistic activities of cyclic analog 6 increased approximately 7.1- and 3.4-fold, respectively.(20) However, the μ-opioid receptor agonistic activity of analog 6 had a 2.5-fold lower than that of fentanyl in cAMP assay.
    Table 3. Functional Activities of Multifunctional Peptide Analogs in cAMP Assays at Opioid Receptors
     μ-opioid receptorκ-opioid receptorδ-opioid receptor
    compd.log EC50aEC50 (nM)Emax (%)log EC50aEC50 (nM)Emax (%)log EC50aEC50 (nM)Emax (%)
    fentanyl–7.76 ± 0.1717.287.8 ± 5.5cccccc
    0–6.51 ± 0.15b308b92.4 ± 9.7b–6.25 ± 0.25b564b106 ± 20.7b–6.23 ± 0.06b587b82.2 ± 3.7b
    1–5.81 ± 0.42155078.6 ± 12.3–6.74 ± 0.2318478.6 ± 7.8–6.66 ± 0.2321835.8 ± 2.9
    2–6.66 ± 0.3022175.2 ± 7.7–6.24 ± 0.1358184.0 ± 5.2–6.29 ± 0.2951446.1 ± 6.1
    3–6.75 ± 0.2017888.0 ± 7.0–7.13 ± 0.2375.192.3 ± 11.0–6.70 ± 0.2219950.4 ± 4.0
    4–6.77 ± 0.2017183.9 ± 6.1–5.64 ± 0.262296114 ± 15.7–6.66 ± 0.2721958.3 ± 4.8
    5–6.10 ± 0.2878873.8 ± 8.4–6.51 ± 0.2630792.6 ± 11.0–6.79 ± 0.2716263.6 ± 7.6
    6–7.37 ± 0.3043.181.5 ± 7.8–6.06 ± 0.2886673.0 ± 4.1–6.76 ± 0.1717465.1 ± 4.2
    7–5.42 ± 0.28382878.6 ± 10.1–6.13 ± 0.2074368.6 ± 6.5–6.31 ± 0.2449060.3 ± 5.8
    8–6.71 ± 1.2919682.0 ± 8.5–5.61 ± 0.27245668.5 ± 8.8–6.70 ± 0.2920063.6 ± 6.6
    a

    The log EC50 ± standard error is a logarithmic result of linear analysis of data collected from at least three separate experiments performed in duplicates (n = 3).

    b

    Data cited from our previous report.(20)

    c

    The data were not determined.

    In cells expressing the κ-opioid receptor, the linear peptides 1–3 showed slightly improved potencies for κ-opioid receptor agonistic activities compared to that of the parent peptide 0.(20) However, cyclizations at positions 2 and 5 of the linear peptides 1–3 slightly decreased their potencies for the κ-opioid receptor. In addition, the multiple substitutions of positions 2 and 5 with d-Cys (4 and 8) exhibited drastically reduced potencies for the κ-opioid receptor. Similarly, our previous study demonstrated that replacement Gln5 of peptide 0 with d-type amino acids resulted in the loss of κ-opioid receptor agonistic activity.(21) Thus, these findings suggested that the stereochemical features of amino acids at positions 2 and 5 of the parent peptide 0 were important for κ-opioid receptor agonistic activity. In addition, compared to the parent peptide, cyclic analog 6 showed a slight loss of κ-opioid receptor agonistic activity (1.5-fold potency). Furthermore, the functional activities of these analogs at NPFF receptors are summarized in Table 4. All analogs concentration dependently exhibited agonistic activities in cells stably expressing NPFF1 or NPFF2 receptors. Our recent data obtained from the single substitution at the 5 position of peptide 0 with d-type amino acids indicated that the stereochemical configuration of amino acid at position 5 played an important role in the potency for the NPFF1 receptor agonistic activity.(21) Consistent with the previous study,(21) the peptides containing Cys5 (analogs 1, 2, 5, and 6) had significantly improved agonistic activities for the NPFF1 receptor in comparison to the analogs containing d-Cys5 (analogs 3, 4, 7, and 8). However, the NPFF1 receptor agonistic activities of these analogs were not significantly affected by disulfide cyclization at positions 2 and 5. In addition, for the NPFF2 receptor, the substitutions of positions 2 and 5 with Cys or/and d-Cys (analogs 1–4) had significant decreases in agonistic activities compared to 0.(21) On the other hand, the cyclization by the disulfide linkages improved 3.7- to 27.7-fold potencies for NPFF2 receptor agonistic activity compared to their corresponding linear peptides, implying that the cyclization was an effective modification to improve the NPFF2 receptor agonistic activity. Notably, compared to the parent peptide 0, the NPFF1 and NPFF2 receptor agonistic activities of cyclic analog 6 improved approximately 78.8- and 9.6-fold, respectively.
    Table 4. Functional Activities of Multifunctional Peptide Analogs in cAMP Assays at NPFF Receptors
     NPFFR1NPFFR2
    compd.log EC50aEC50 (nM)Emax (%)log EC50aEC50 (nM)Emax (%)
    0–6.23 ± 0.18b591b59.9 ± 9.3b–6.73 ± 0.36b185b58.4 ± 15.3b
    1–7.60 ± 0.4024.979.7 ± 11.6–6.12 ± 0.4075262.9 ± 11.5
    2–7.76 ± 0.1517.578.5 ± 3.6–6.27 ± 0.4153246.6 ± 4.5
    3–6.67 ± 0.2321681.8 ± 6.2–6.16 ± 0.1569755.1 ± 3.3
    4–6.10 ± 0.1578885.7 ± 5.9–6.14 ± 0.7771958.4 ± 20.4
    5–7.49 ± 0.1732.580.2 ± 3.9–6.92 ± 0.2712079.6 ± 9.3
    6–8.12 ± 0.197.575.9 ± 3.5–7.72 ± 0.3019.253.3 ± 2.8
    7–6.45 ± 0.2035482.8 ± 6.0–6.77 ± 0.3716861.6 ± 7.5
    8–6.44 ± 0.2336175.6 ± 7.6–6.72 ± 0.3019274.6 ± 7.2
    a

    The log EC50 ± standard error is a logarithmic result of linear analysis of data collected from at least three separate experiments performed in duplicates (n = 3).

    b

    Data cited from our previous report.(20)

    Taken together, the following structure and conformational preferences for opioid and NPFF receptors seemed to be obtained from the in vitro cAMP assays: (1) replacing the amino acids side chain at positions 2 and 5 with the methanethiol group (−CH2–SH) (analog 2) of 0 and maintaining the chirality feature (d/l-configuration at positions 2 and 5) significantly increased the NPFF1 receptor agonistic activity, with approximately 33.7-fold potency compared to 0, but showed only a slight increase or decrease in potencies at the NPFF2 and opioid receptors. (2) Incorporating d/l-configuration amino acids at positions 2 or/and 5 of analog 2 had significant effects on the activities for μ-, κ-opioid, and NPFF1 receptors but not the potencies at the δ-opioid and NPFF2 receptors. Simultaneous substitution with l-Cys (analog 1) or d-Cys (analog 4) at positions 2 and 5 decreased activities for μ- and κ-opioid receptors, respectively, with approximately 4- to 7-fold potencies compared to analog 2. In addition, substitution of l-amino acid at position 5 with d-amino acid (analogs 3 and 4) greatly decreased agonistic activities for the NPFF1 receptor, with approximately 12- to 45-fold potencies compared to analog 2. (3) Disulfide cyclization at positions 2 and 5 significantly increased the NPFF2 receptor agonistic activities, with approximately 3.7- to 27.7-fold potencies compared to their corresponding linear peptides, while maintaining their activity at the NPFF1 and opioid receptors (except analog 7). However, one small exception was the analog 7 which maintained δ-opioid and NPFF receptor agonistic activities roughly equal to their corresponding linear analog 3 and 22- and 10-fold less potencies at the μ- and κ-opioid receptors than its corresponding linear peptide 3, respectively.

    Stability Studies in Brain and Plasma

    The brain and plasma stabilities of these analogs were evaluated by incubation in 15% mouse brain homogenate or 100% plasma for 240 min. The half-life values of these analogs were calculated using the first-order kinetic equation, and the obtained data are summarized in Table 5. Our results indicated that the half-life values of these cyclic analogs 5–8 were ranging from 58.0 ± 6.1 to 255 ± 30.3 min in the brain homogenate, which were longer than that of peptide 0 (42.43 ± 6.03 min).(20) These findings implied that these cyclized peptides 6–8 possessed improved enzymatic stabilities in the brain homogenate compared to the parent peptide 0. To our surprise, our preliminary results have shown that the linear analogs 1–4 could be disulfide-cyclized in 15% mouse brain homogenate without the cyclization reagent but not in 100% plasma. Therefore, it was difficult to provide the data about the half-life values of these linear analogs 1–4 in the brain homogenate.
    Table 5. Half-Lives of Multifunctional Peptide Analogs in Brain and Plasma
      half-lives in brain and plasmaa
    compd.names15% mouse brain (min)100% plasma (min)
    1OFP001b29.6 ± 2.1
    2OFP002b27.9 ± 3.8
    3OFP003b31.4 ± 3.7
    4OFP004b30.9 ± 2.2
    5OFP00558.0 ± 6.128.9 ± 2.9
    6OFP006173 ± 36.753.6 ± 8.9
    7OFP007229 ± 6.6017.0 ± 2.2
    8OFP008255 ± 30.314.6 ± 0.1
    a

    The half-live values are collected from at least three separate experiments (n = 3).

    b

    The data cannot be determined.

    In addition, the half-life values of these cyclic analogs and their corresponding linear peptides were ranging from 14.6 ± 0.1 to 53.6 ± 8.9 min in plasma. However, the recent studies have shown that the half-life of the parent peptide 0 was 44.9 ± 2.1 min in plasma.(22) Therefore, these results indicated that modification of amino acid side chains or d/l-configuration at positions 2 or/and 5 of 0 slightly decreased the plasma stabilities (analogs 1–4). In addition, cyclizations at positions 2 and 5 slightly decreased the stabilities of analogs 5, 7, and 8 while increasing the stability of the cyclic analog 6.

    In Vivo Brain Uptake Study

    To investigate the brain penetration of cyclic analog 6, mice were intravenously administered with analog 6 at a dose of 1 mg/kg. Mice were decapitated at different time points after injection, and the brains and plasma were isolated and quantitated by liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry (LC–MS/MS) analysis. The time course of analog 6 in the whole brain and plasma are displayed in Figure 1. The brain/plasma (B/P) ratio in vivo is a good standard for measuring the extent of brain uptake for drug discovery. In addition, a previous study has indicated that a high B/P (B/P > 0.3) ratio was indicative of brain penetration.(35) The B/P value of morphine was 0.74, while that of morphine-6 β-glucuronide was 0.05.(36) The AUCs of the degradation curve of analog 6 in the whole brain and plasma were 3.87 μg·min/g and 3.78 μg·min/mL, respectively, and the B/P AUC ratio of analog 6 was 1.02. Therefore, this result indicated a significant BBB permeability of analog 6 after intravenous administration.

    Supraspinal Antinociception Studies

    The analgesic activities of all analogs were assessed in the radiant heat tail-flick test. The results of supraspinal antinociceptive ED50 values are presented in Table 6. In the previous study, 0 showed nontolerance-forming antinociception with an ED50 value of 390 pmol after intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) injection.(20) In this study, supraspinal administration of fentanyl produced a significant analgesic effect with an ED50 value of 344 pmol, while analogs 1–8 produced potent antinociception with ED50 values ranging from 0.001 to 182 pmol after i.c.v. administration. These data indicated that the antinociceptive potencies of these analogs were more potent than those of the parent peptide 0 and fentanyl. In addition, the dose- and time-related antinociceptive effects of fentanyl and the analogs after i.c.v. administration are presented in Figure 2 and Supporting Information (Figure S1). The durations of the antinociceptive activities of the fentanyl and peptide 0 were 1 and 1.5 h, respectively, after supraspinal injection.(20) In contrast, the supraspinal antinociception induced by most of the analogs (except analogs 1 and 5) lasted at least for 3 h.
    Table 6. Antinociception and Tolerance Evaluation After the i.c.v. Administration of Multifunctional Peptide Analogs via the Mouse Tail-Flick Test
    compd.namesED50a pmol/mouse (95% CI)8 days tolerance
     fentanyl344 (277–429)tolerance
    0BN-9b390 (332–464)bno toleranceb
    1OFP001150 (123–184)no tolerance
    2OFP0020.60 (0.45–0.78)no tolerance
    3OFP0036.42 (4.90–8.42)no tolerance
    4OFP0041.13 (0.82–1.56)no tolerance
    5OFP005182 (158–210)no tolerance
    6OFP0060.014 (0.011–0.020)no tolerance
    7OFP0070.21 (0.16–0.28)no tolerance
    8OFP0080.001 (0.0004–0.002)no tolerance
    a

    Analgesic ED50 is determined by the highest analgesic point.

    b

    Data cited from our previous study.(20)

    At the supraspinal level, Figure 2 showed that analogs 6 and 8 exhibited dose-related antinociceptive responses, achieving approximately 90% of the maximal possible effects at a dose of 30 pmol (analog 6, F4,53 = 431.1, P < 0.001; analog 8, F5,50 = 233.1, P < 0.001). Compared to the μ-opioid receptor selective agonist fentanyl, analogs 6–8 exhibited more potent antinociception (Table 6). Another important feature of analogs 6 and 8 was that their antinociceptive effects lasted for 4 h, which was 4-fold longer duration than that produced by fentanyl under the equipotent dose.
    To evaluate the roles of opioid receptors in the supraspinal antinociception of all analogs, the effects of the selective opioid antagonists on their central antinociceptions are shown in Figure 3A,C and Supporting Information (Figure S2) (analog 1, F10,84 = 149.8, P < 0.001; analog 2, F10,85 = 85.92, P < 0.001; analog 3, F10,86 = 123.8, P < 0.001; analog 4, F10,84 = 199.8, P < 0.001; analog 5, F10,87 = 240.6, P < 0.001; analog 6, F10,89 = 155.4, P < 0.001; analog 7, F10,92 = 129.1, P < 0.001; analog 8, F10,86 = 229.2, P < 0.001). To our surprise, the supraspinal antinociceptive activities of these four cyclic disulfide peptides were mediated by different opioid receptor subtypes (Table 8). In addition, the linear peptides produced supraspinal antinociception via the mechanisms similar to their corresponding cyclic analogs. It was difficult to explain these exceptional cases. However, the different pharmacological mechanisms involved in the central antinociception of these analogs might partially associate with their different functional selectivities at the opioid receptors in cAMP assays. Both analogs 1 and 5 produced central antinociception via δ- and κ-opioid receptors, which were consistent with their improved potencies at the δ- and κ-opioid receptors but a slight loss of μ-opioid activity in vitro. In addition, both analogs 4 and 8 produced central antinociception independent of the κ-opioid receptor, which might be due to their reduced κ-opioid receptor agonistic activities in in vitro functional assays.
    At the supraspinal level, the high antinociceptive potencies of cyclic peptides 6–8 might associate with the multifunctional agonism at opioid receptors and their improved enzymatic stabilities in the brain homogenate. As described above, cyclic analogs 6–8 disappeared in the brain homogenate with half-life values ranging from 173 to 255 min, which might be, at least partially, used to explain their long-lasting antinociception after supraspinal administration. It was notable that the μ-opioid receptor agonistic activity of cyclic analog 6 exhibited an approximately 7-fold increase than analog 0. In addition, analog 6 had an improved δ- and κ-opioid receptor agonistic activities. In fact, our results also indicated that the analog 6-induced supraspinal antinociception was blocked by the μ-opioid receptor antagonist β-funaltrexamine (β-FNA) and partially reduced by the δ- and κ-opioid receptor antagonists (analog 6, F10,89 = 155.4, P < 0.001). The synergistic effect of μ-, δ-, and κ-opioid receptor agonists on antinociception has been shown in the previous studies.(37,38) Thus, the multifunctional opioid agonism of analog 6 might be also used to explain its high antinociceptive potency. However, analog 8-induced supraspinal antinociception was partially blocked by the μ-opioid receptor antagonist (analog 8, F10,86 = 229.2, P < 0.001), independent of δ- and κ-opioid receptors (P > 0.05). In theory, it was difficult to explain the high antinociceptive potency of analog 8 because of its low potency at the μ-opioid receptor. Thus, we could not rule out the possibility that other receptors besides opioid receptors might be involved in the potent antinociceptive effect of analog 8.
    Based on their multifunctional agonistic properties at the opioid and NPFF receptors, we further examined whether NPFF receptors were involved in the central antinociceptive effects of these analogs. A previous study has shown that NPFF exhibited antiopioid activities at the supraspinal level.(16) Our previous studies have shown that the NPFF pharmacophore of peptide 0 and DN-9 exhibited antiopioid activities at the supraspinal level.(20,21) As expected, in Figure 3B,D and Supporting Information (Figure S3), the antinociception of all analogs were significantly potentiated by the NPFF receptor antagonist 1-adamantanecarbonyl-Arg-Phe-NH2 (RF9) (10 nmol, 5 min) after supraspinal administration (analog 1, F4,37 = 197.4, P < 0.001; analog 2, F4,37 = 254.8, P < 0.001; analog 3, F4,37 = 161.1, P < 0.001; analog 4, F4,37 = 184.6, P < 0.001; analog 5, F4,39 = 179.9, P < 0.001; analog 6, F4,38 = 277.8, P < 0.001; analog 7, F4,39 = 138.6, P < 0.001; analog 8, F4,39 = 215.6, P < 0.001), which further supported NPFF receptor-mediated agonism of these analogs in vivo.(20,21) In our present studies, supraspinal injection of the NPFF receptor antagonist RF9 attenuated the antiopioid activities of the NPFF pharmacophore and further potentiated the μ-opioid-induced analgesia of these compounds after supraspinal injection, which was consistent with our previous studies.(20,21)

    Subcutaneous Antinociception Studies

    The antinociception of these analogs was also investigated after s.c. injection in the radiant heat tail-flick test. As shown in Table 7, our work showed that s.c. administration of fentanyl produced a potent analgesic effect with an ED50 value of 0.03 μmol/kg, which was consistent with the previous studies.(39−41) After peripheral administration, these analogs produced potent antinociception with ED50 values ranging from 0.002 to 0.24 μmol/kg, indicating that their antinociceptive potencies were more potent than that of the parent peptide 0 (1.37 μmol/kg). In addition, the dose- and time-related antinociceptive effects of fentanyl and these analogs after s.c. administration are presented in Figure 4 and Supporting Information (Figure S4). The antinociceptive effects induced by fentanyl and peptide 0 lasted for 1 h after s.c. injection. Similarly, the antinociceptive effects of analogs 1 and 5 lasted for 1.5 h following s.c. administration. In contrast, the antinociception induced by the cyclic analogs 6–8 and their corresponding linear peptides 2–4 remained 4 and 3 h, respectively. Notably, after peripheral administration, analogs 6 and 8 were more potent than fentanyl. Our results showed that both analogs 6 and 8 exhibited dose-dependent antinociceptive responses, achieving approximately 80% of the maximal possible effects at a dose of 0.09 μmol/kg (analog 6, F3,34 = 302.9, P < 0.001; analog 8, F3,35 = 266.5, P < 0.001). Another important feature of analogs 6 and 8 was that their antinociceptive effects lasted for 4 h.
    Table 7. Antinociception and Tolerance Evaluation After the s.c. Administration of Multifunctional Peptide Analogs via the Mouse Tail-Flick Test
    compd.namesED50a μmol/kg (95% CI)8 days tolerance
     fentanyl0.03 (0.02–0.03)tolerance
    0BN-91.37 (1.16–1.60)b
    1OFP0010.24 (0.16–0.35)b
    2OFP0020.13 (0.09–0.18)b
    3OFP0030.10 (0.07–0.16)b
    4OFP0040.06 (0.04–0.09)b
    5OFP0050.18 (0.13–0.26)no tolerance
    6OFP0060.003 (0.002–0.004)no tolerance
    7OFP0070.003 (0.002–0.004)no tolerance
    8OFP0080.002 (0.001–0.003)no tolerance
    a

    Analgesic ED50 is determined by the highest analgesic point.

    b

    The data were not determined.

    It is well-known that both morphine and fentanyl can pass through the BBB and activate the opioid receptors in the brain after s.c. injection.(42−45) To determine whether the central opioid receptors were involved in the antinociception induced by these novel analogs after s.c. injection, the classical opioid receptor antagonist naloxone (Nal) and the peripherally restricted opioid receptors antagonist naloxone methiodide (NALM) were further used in this study, as shown in Figure 5, Table 8, and Supporting Information (Figure S5). Consistent with the previous study,(46) our present work demonstrates that the analgesic effect induced by fentanyl after s.c. administration was completely blocked by s.c. injection of Nal (1 mg/kg, 10 min) (F7,60 = 249.7, P < 0.001) but not by s.c. injection of NALM (1 mg/kg, 10 min) (P > 0.05).(42,43) In contrast, s.c. fentanyl-induced antinociception was also reduced by i.c.v. injection of NALM (5 nmol, 10 min) (F7,60 = 249.7, P < 0.001). These findings supported the BBB permeability of fentanyl. Similar to fentanyl, the four cyclic analogs 5–8 had improved BBB permeabilities and produced antinociceptive effects through opioid receptors in the brain (analog 5, F7,61 = 199.7, P < 0.001; analog 6, F7,67 = 92.8, P < 0.001; analog 7, F7,65 = 88.6, P < 0.001; analog 8, F7,71 = 97.4, P < 0.001). In contrast, the antinociceptive responses induced by the linear peptides including the parent peptide 0 were inhibited by s.c. injection of Nal and NALM but not by i.c.v. injection of NALM (analog 1, F7,62 = 129.6, P < 0.001; analog 2, F7,59 = 181.6, P < 0.001; analog 3, F7,59 = 142.5, P < 0.001; analog 4, F7,62 = 228.0, P < 0.001), implying that these linear peptides produced antinociception via peripheral opioid receptors after s.c. administration. These results were consistent with the recent data that 0 could not cross the BBB.(22,23)
    Table 8. Antinociceptive Profiles of Multifunctional Peptide Analogs
    compd.namesopioid antagonism (i.c.v.)effects of RF9 (i.c.v.)BBB permeability
     fentanylopioid receptorsnoyes
    0BN-9aμ-, κ-opioidapotentiationanoa
    1OFP001opioid receptorspotentiationno
    2OFP002opioid receptorspotentiationno
    3OFP003opioid receptorspotentiationno
    4OFP004opioid receptorspotentiationno
    5OFP005κ-, δ-opioidpotentiationyes
    6OFP006μ-, κ-, δ-opioidpotentiationyes
    7OFP007μ-, κ-opioidpotentiationyes
    8OFP008μ-opioidpotentiationyes
    a

    Data cited from our previous study.(20,22)

    In addition, we investigated the role of central and peripheral NPFF receptors in the antinociception induced by these compounds after s.c. administration. As shown in Supporting Information (Figure S6), our present results suggested that the peripheral NPFF system was not involved in the analgesic effects induced by these analogs after s.c. injection (P > 0.05). In fact, our previous results have shown that the antinociceptive effect of s.c. injection of analog 0 was not affected by peripheral injection of the NPFF receptors antagonist RF9.(22,23) Consistent with our results, the previous study has shown that only a small quantity of the NPFF receptors was localized in the peripheral tissues.(47)
    As shown in Figure 6, the antinociceptive effects of analogs 6 and 8 after s.c. injection were potentiated by supraspinal RF9 (10 nmol, 5 min) (analog 6, F4,37 = 190.0, P < 0.001; analog 8, F4,37 = 154.8, P < 0.001) but not by s.c. RF9 (5 mg/kg, 5 min), in alignment with the results obtained from NPFF2–/– mice on a C57BL/6 background in which s.c. analog 6-induced antinociceptive effects were significantly increased compared to the wild-type (WT) mice on a C57BL/6 background (analog 6, F3,26 = 6.7, P < 0.01). However, s.c. administration of the corresponding linear analog 2 produced antinociception in NPFF2–/– mice with an antinociceptive potency similar to that in WT mice (P > 0.05). These pharmacological data further supported the abilities of analogs 6 and 8 but not their corresponding linear peptides to cross the BBB and activate NPFF receptors in the brain. Taken together, the pharmacokinetic and pharmacological studies confirmed the BBB permeability of analog 6. These pharmacological data indicated that the cyclization by the disulfide linkage was an effective modification to improve BBB permeabilities of these linear analogs of 0.
    After s.c. administration, cyclic disulfide analogs 6–8 exhibited improved antinociceptive potencies and duration of action in comparison to their corresponding linear peptides 2–4 and the parent peptide 0 in this study. However, the cyclized peptides possessed improved enzymatic stabilities in the brain homogenate but not in plasma compared to the parent peptide 0. The potent antinociceptive effects of s.c. cyclic analogs 6–8 might be explained by their improved BBB permeabilities, which resulted in the activation of the opioid receptors in the brain following s.c. administration and producing potent antinociceptive effects with improved duration of action of 4 h.
    Taken together, based on the data obtained from in vitro pharmacokinetics and in vivo animal behavior experiments, we could conclude that the linear analogs 1–4 could not pass through the BBB in a manner similar to the parent peptide 0. However, the cyclization modification greatly increased the BBB permeabilities of cyclic analogs 5–8 compared to their corresponding linear analogs and the parent peptide 0.

    Antinociceptive Tolerance Studies

    The development of analgesic tolerance of these analogs was further measured in the radiant heat tail-flick test, and analgesic tolerance was evaluated by comparing the daily tail-flick thresholds. At the supraspinal level, the highest analgesic doses of all analogs were i.c.v. injected once daily for 8 consecutive days, as shown in Table 6, Figure 7A, and Supporting Information (Figure S7). Compared to day 1, the analgesic effect induced by i.c.v. administration of fentanyl significantly decreased on the test day 4 (P < 0.001), demonstrating that the tolerance developed to the supraspinal antinociception induced by fentanyl, as described previously.(48−53) In contrast, all analogs produced equivalent antinociceptive effects over 8 days course after i.c.v. administration (P > 0.05). Furthermore, in Table 7, Figure 7B, and Supporting Information (Figure S8), the tolerance induced by fentanyl began to develop on day 4 following s.c. administration (P < 0.001), while s.c. administration of these cyclic disulfide analogs 5–8 produced antinociceptive effects without loss of potencies over 8 days (P > 0.05). Indeed, our previous studies have shown that the mixed opioid/NPFF receptor agonists EN-9, 0 (BN-9), and DN-9 produced potent and nontolerance-forming antinociception after various routes of administration.(19−21)

    Opioid-like Side Effect Studies of Analogs 6 and 8

    Among these analogs, analogs 6 and 8 exhibited the highest antinociceptive potencies compared to the parent peptide 0 when given at both central and peripheral levels. We further investigated the side effects of analogs 6 and 8 at the highest analgesic doses.
    The effects of the highest analgesic doses of analogs 6 and 8 after i.c.v. and s.c. administrations on motor coordination were investigated to rule out the false positive results of analgesic effects. As shown in Figure 8A,B, there were no effect on locomotor activity in mice after i.c.v. and s.c. administrations of analogs 6 and 8 in comparison to saline (P > 0.05).
    Next, the behavioral effects of peripheral administration of analogs 6 and 8 were evaluated in three experimental paradigms including the classical responses of opioids to acute hyperlocomotion, conditioned place preference (CPP), and Nal-precipitated withdrawal.
    The activation of the dopaminergic reward circuits plays an important role in the addiction of opioid analgesics and results in an acute hyperlocomotion in mice.(54) The acute hyperlocomotive responses induced by s.c. administration of fentanyl and analogs 6 and 8 were tested using an open field assay. As shown in Figure 9A,B, s.c. administration of fentanyl significantly increased the total travelled distance (F3,29 = 2.996, P < 0.05) compared to saline, which was consistent with the previous study.(55) In contrast, mice treated with analogs 6 and 8 produced slight but not statistically significant increases in the locomotor activity after peripheral administration (P > 0.05).
    As shown in Figure 9C, the effects of fentanyl and analogs 6 and 8 on reward effects were investigated with an unbiased CPP equipment. Consistent with the previous reported data,(55,56) s.c. administration of fentanyl produced significant CPP response after the conditioning exposure compared to saline (F3,35 = 11.95, P < 0.001). In a manner similar to fentanyl, s.c. administration of analog 8 also produced a significant CPP response (F3,35 = 11.95, P < 0.001). However, analog 6 did not induce significant CPP response compared to saline at the effective analgesic dose (P > 0.05). These findings indicated that analog 6 exhibited a reduced activation of reward circuits in comparison to fentanyl and analog 8.
    Behaviors precipitated by the classical opioid antagonist Nal (10 mg/kg, s.c.) in mice previously treated with opioids were evaluated, and Nal precipitated the characteristic withdrawal symptom of jumping. Figure 9D showed that s.c. injection of fentanyl significantly increased the jumping counts after Nal injection compared to saline (F3,33 = 13.11, P < 0.001), which was consistent with the previous studies.(41,57) In contrast, the incidences of jumping induced by analogs 6 and 8 had no significant difference compared to saline (P > 0.05), suggesting the reduced withdrawal symptoms of analogs 6 and 8.
    The constipation is complicated under the use of opioid analgesics for pain control. Lastly, the effects of analogs 6 and 8 on gastrointestinal motility were also investigated in mice. As shown in Figure 10A,B, s.c. injection of analogs 6 and 8 caused dose-dependent inhibition of gastrointestinal motility compared to saline (analog 6, F3,29 = 15.92, P < 0.001; analog 8, F3,28 = 18.36, P < 0.001). In the gastrointestinal transit (GIT) test, the ED50 values of analogs 6 and 8 were 2.25 and 0.07 μmol/kg after s.c. administration, respectively, and ED50 values of the gastrointestinal motility inhibition induced by analogs 6 and 8 were 750- and 35-fold higher than their analgesic ED50 values, respectively, when given at the same route. In other words, neither analog 6 nor analog 8 exhibited significant gastrointestinal motility inhibition at effective antinociceptive doses.
    Taken together, our present data show that the rewarding effects, withdrawal reactions, and constipation of analogs 6 and 8 were significantly reduced in comparison to the classical opioid analgesic fentanyl. More importantly, analog 6 that induced powerful antinociception via the μ-, δ-, and κ-opioid receptors exhibited weaker side effects on rewarding effects and constipation than analog 8. In our previous studies, the multifunctional opioid/NPFF receptor agonists EN-9, 0 (BN-9), and DN-9 induced little inhibition of GIT after various routes of administration.(19,20,22) Thus, our present data further support that the multifunctional opioid/NPFF receptor agonists possessed reduced side effects on constipation than the classical opioids. In the previous study, in a manner similar to morphine, the parent peptide 0 produced dose-related CPP after supraspinal injection.(18) Similarly, our present work also demonstrates that both fentanyl and analog 8 induced significant CPP responses after s.c. injection. Based on their BBB permeabilities of fentanyl and analog 8, the present results are consistent with the aforementioned studies that they could pass through BBB. Compared to fentanyl, analog 6 had no significant CPP response. It seemed difficult to explain the conflicting findings between analogs 6 and 8 in CPP experiment, which might be due to the different pharmacological mechanisms that were involved in the central antinociception of analogs 6 and 8. The aforementioned results demonstrated that analog 6 produced supraspinal antinociception via μ-, δ-, and κ-opioid receptors, while analog 8 exerted μ-opioid receptor-mediated antinociception. Thus, the limited reward activity of analog 6 might result from its multifunctional agonistic profiles toward μ-, δ-, and κ-opioid receptors in vivo.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The parent peptide 0 (BN-9), a multifunctional opioid/NPFF receptor agonist, produced nontolerance-forming antinociception with limited side effects.(20,22) To improve its therapeutic efficacy for translational-medical development, we synthesized four cyclic disulfide analogs incorporating Cys and/or d-Cys with the intentions of (1) probing and improving BBB permeability, (2) improving bioavailability and duration of antinociceptive action, and (3) further balancing the efficacies at the opioid and NPFF receptors. In this study, the cyclized analogs and their linear counterparts functioned as multifunctional agonists at both opioid and NPFF receptors in vitro. Among these new analogs, cyclized analog 6 showed the highest agonist activity at the μ-opioid and NPFF receptors. Compared to the parent peptide 0, the μ- and δ-opioid, NPFF1, and NPFF2 receptor activities of the analog 6 improved approximately 7.1-, 3.4-, 78.8-, and 9.6-fold, respectively.
    Supraspinal and s.c. administrations of analogs 6 and 8 produced more potent and prolonged analgesic actions (4 h) in comparison to fentanyl. As expected, the cyclized analog 6 had a greater BBB permeability and an improved enzymatic stability in the brain homogenate compared to the parent peptide BN-9. To our surprise, the supraspinal antinociceptive activities of these four cyclic disulfide peptides were mediated by different pharmacological mechanisms.
    Based on the antinociceptive efficacy evaluations, analogs 6 and 8 were selected for further in vivo side-effect studies. Compared to fentanyl, the side effects of analog 6 on tolerance, rewarding effect, withdrawal reaction, and constipation were significantly reduced. This work showed that the multifunctional opioid and NPFF receptor agonist analog 6 was a highly promising compound as a novel analgesic for pain treatment with limited side effects.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemicals and Drugs

    All natural amino acids, non-natural amino acids, and coupling reagents were purchased from GL Biochem Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Rink amide 4-methylbenzhydrylamine (MBHA) resin (100–200 mesh, substitution 0.44 mmol/g) was purchased from Nankai Hecheng Science & Technology Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). All organic chemicals were purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. (Beijing, China). [3H]cAMP (50 Ci/mmol) was the product of PerkinElmer (Boston, MA, USA). In addition, protein kinase A (PKA), forskolin, 3-isobutyl-1-methylxanthine (IBMX), and the opioid antagonists including Nal, NALM, β-FNA, nor-binaltorphimine (nor-BNI), and naltrindole (NTI) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA).

    Peptide Synthesis

    The peptides were synthesized by a well-defined Fmoc solid-phase methodology on Rink amide MBHA resin following our previous report.(21) All couplings of amino acids were performed using HBTU/HOBT/DIEA (1:1:2) in DMF as described previously.(21) We used 1% piperidine and 1% 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene in DMF to deprotect the Fmoc group. Specifically, cyclization reactions of the cyclic peptides were carried out on the resin using an excess of iodine (8 equiv) in DMF and were stirred for 4 h. Upon completion of the oxidation, the resin was washed with dichloromethane (DCM) (2 × 3 min), 2% anti-ascorbic acid in DMF (2 × 3 min), NMP (5 × 3 min), and DCM (2 × 3 min).(58) Then, the resin was dried in a vacuum at least for 3 h and was cleaved with trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)/triisopropylsilane (Tis)/1,2-ethanedithiol (EDT)/H2O (94:1:2.5:2.5) or TFA/Tis/H2O (95:2.5:2.5) for 3 h. Subsequently, the evaporated filtrate was precipitated with ice ether and extracted with 10% acetic acid solution and then was lyophilized to get the crude peptides.
    The peptides were purified by semipreparative RP-HPLC. Fractions containing the purified peptides were pooled and lyophilized. Molecular weights were measured by the positive ion mode under ESI methods (ESI-Q-TOF maXis-4G, Bruker Daltonics, Germany). The purities of the purified peptides were analyzed by analytical HPLC with the C18 column (XBridge BEH 130 Prep, 5 μm, 250 mm × 4.6 mm) with a linear gradient of 10–80% (system 1) or 10–100% (system 2) of solvent A at a flow rate of 1 mL/min in 30 min (A, acetonitrile with 0.1% TFA; B, water with 0.1% TFA) and confirmed to be of ≥95% purity for all peptides as determined by UV absorption at 220 nm. The purities for analogs: analog 1, system 1: 97.4%, system 2: 98.6%; analog 2, system 1: 97.2%, system 2: 99.0%; analog 3, system 1: 95.1%, system 2: 96.1%; analog 4, system 1: 99.5%, system 2: 95.7%; analog 5, system 1: 95.5%, system 2: 97.4%; analog 6, system 1: 95.8%, system 2: 100.0%; analog 7, system 1: 95.4%, system 2: 95.6%; andanalog 8, system 1: 96.3%, system 2: 96.7%.

    Animals

    Six- to eight-week-old male Kunming and C57BL/6 mice were obtained from the Experimental Animal Centre of Lanzhou University. Six- to eight-week-old male NPFF2 receptor-deficient (NPFF2–/–) mice on the C57BL/6 background were purchased from Cyagen Biosciences Inc. (Suzhou, China). Mice were maintained on a 12 h light/dark cycle maintained at 22 ± 2 °C and given free access to food and water. All experimental animals were carried out in accordance with the European Community guidelines and performed in accordance with the European Community guidelines (2010/63/EU). The Ethics Committee and Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Lanzhou University approved all animal protocols. All mice were used only once in this research.

    In Vitro Functional Assays (cAMP Assays)

    cAMP assays were performed on HEK-293A cells that stably expressed the μ-, κ-, δ-opioid, NPFF1, or NPFF2 receptors as described previously.(21) HEK-293A cells were seeded in 24-well microtiter plates and cultured for more than 20 h. The medium contained 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 μg/mL streptomycin, 100 IU/mL penicillin, and 400 mg/mL G418 which was used to maintain cells expressing opioid or NPFF receptors. Cell cultures were kept at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2. At the beginning of the assay, after removing the culture medium, cells were incubated at 37 °C for 10 min in serum-free medium containing 1 mM IBMX and then were incubated at 37 °C for 30 min after adding various concentrations of drugs and 5 μM forskolin. After the incubation, the final cAMP was extracted and assayed by a competition PKA binding assay. We used the standard curve that was constructed using cAMP standards to calculate the concentration of cAMP.

    Drug Administration

    i.c.v. administration was similar to the previous report.(20) In brief, male Kunming mice were anaesthetized with pentobarbital sodium (80 mg/kg, i.p.) and placed in a stereotaxic frame. The stainless-steel guide cannulas were implanted and cemented at 3.0 mm posterior to the bregma, 1.0 mm lateral and 3.0 mm ventral from the surface of the skull. After surgery, the mice were allowed to recover at least for 4 days before use. Drugs were administrated into the lateral ventricle in a volume of 4 μL per mouse followed by 1 μL of saline to flush in the drug at a constant rate of 10 μL/min by using a 25 μL microsyringe.
    For s.c. administration, drugs or vehicles were given in a volume of 10 mL/kg using a disposable 1 mL syringe at the site of back of the neck for each animal.
    For i.v. administration, mice were placed in restrainers and the tail veins were wiped with 75% alcohol to dilate blood vessels. The disposable 1 mL syringe was inserted into the tail vein at an angle of approximately 25°. Drugs were given at a volume of 10 mL/kg.

    Stability Studies in Brain and Plasma

    The enzymatic stability experiments of analogs were conducted with 15% mouse brain homogenate and 100% mouse plasma as previously described.(59) The brain homogenate and plasma were prepared following our previous reports.(20,22) 10 μL of the peptide stock solution (0.01 mM) was added to 190 μL of brain homogenate or plasma. Then, 20 μL volume of solution was quickly removed from the mixture as a 0 min point, and the remaining mixture was then incubated in a water bath at 37 °C. Similarly, 20 μL volume of solution was taken at 5, 10, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 240, and 360 min after peptide addition. An equal volume of ice acetonitrile was immediately added to the removed incubation solution, further shaking and maintaining the sample on ice.(60) After centrifugation at 13,000g for 15 min, the supernatant was collected and frozen at −80 °C until analyzed by RP-HPLC.
    The enzymatic hydrolysis processes of the compounds conformed to the first-order kinetic equation: At = A0 e–Kt, where A0: initial peak area, At: t peak area, K represents elimination rate constant, and t: degradation time. From the above formula, ln At/A0 = −Kt is deducted; then, when At/A0 = 0.5, t1/2 = ln 2/K = 0.693/K. The results were further analyzed by linear regression to calculate the linear correlation R2 value.

    In Vivo Brain Uptake Study

    Male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were given i.v. injection of 1 mg/kg of analog 6 dissolved in saline. The brain and plasma samples were obtained by decapitating the animals at 5, 10, 20, 30, 60, 90, 120, and 240 min and frozen on ice. Three mice were used per time point. The brain was weighed and homogenized in 500 μL of ice-cold phosphate buffer saline (pH 7.4). The plasma samples were separated from blood after centrifugation at 1500g for 5 min. The brain and plasma proteins were removed by precipitation after adding 4-fold the volume of ice acetonitrile. The mixture was shaken, then centrifuged at 20,000g for 30 min, and the supernatant was collected and dried in a CentriVap concentrator (Labconco). The samples were reconstituted in 150 μL of 5% (v/v) acetonitrile and then purified by solid-phase extraction C18 spin columns. Finally, the brain and plasma samples were dried in a CentriVap concentrator and dissolved in an equal volume of 10% (v/v) acetonitrile. Standard curves were also made in the mouse brain homogenate and plasma by mixing a stock solution of analog 6 with the blank brain homogenate and plasma in 1:9 (v/v) ratios and extracted as described for the samples. The samples were stored at −80 °C until further quantitative analysis.
    The quantitative analysis was carried out on an Agilent 1260 HPLC LC–tandem 6460 QTRAP mass spectrometer (LC–MS/MS) system. Samples of 5 μL each were injected onto an Agilent Zorbax Eclipse Plus C18 column (2.1 mm × 50 mm, 1.8 μm) in an oven set at 25 °C. The HPLC mobile phase flow was maintained at 0.3 mL/min with a gradient consisting of water with 0.1% formic acid (A) and acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid (B). The gradient elution was started at 90% A and transitioned in a linear gradient to 10% over 5 min.

    Antinociceptive Testing

    Acute antinociceptive effects were investigated using the radiant heat tail-flick test following our previous reports, and separate groups of male Kunming mice and NPFF2–/– and WT mice on C57BL/6 background (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test.(20,21) In brief, the mouse was gently restrained by hand, and the tail was placed on a radiant heat source 3 cm from the end. The lamp intensity of the tail-flick apparatus was adjusted to achieve a baseline between 3 and 5 s. The latencies to tail-flick were determined before the experimental animals were treated with saline or drugs (i.c.v. or s.c. administration). The animal threshold after treatment depended on each experiment, and maximal latency was 10 s to minimize tissue damage. Data were expressed as a percentage of the maximum possible effect (MPE %) using the following formula

    Rotarod Test

    The effects of drugs on the coordination of mouse movements were evaluated by a rotarod instrument which was described in our previous papers,(20,21) and separate groups of male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test. The mice were trained on the rod (16 rpm) three times a day for 2 consecutive days prior to drug injection. The mice that stayed on the rod for no more than 3 min during training were discarded. The maximum cut-off time was 5 min. On the third day, mice were tested at 10, 20, 30, and 40 min after i.c.v. and s.c. injection of saline and analogs 6 and 8. The results were expressed as the time that each mouse stayed on the rod.

    Antinociceptive Tolerance Test

    Antinociceptive tolerance test was investigated using the tail-flick apparatus following our previous reports,(20,21) and separate groups of male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test. The mice were i.c.v. or s.c. injected with the highest analgesic doses of fentanyl and analogs of 0 once daily for 8 days to evaluate the development of antinociceptive tolerance. The antinociceptive effects were measured once daily after drug administration. The degree of drug tolerance was determined by comparing the changes between the first day and the next few days after drug administration.

    Acute Hyperlocomotion Test

    The acute hyperlocomotion was detected by open field assay,(61) and separate groups of male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test. The experimental apparatus consisted of a 50 × 50 × 40 cm nontopped black plexiglass box and a set of motion monitoring system (PMT-100, Chengdu Technology & Market Co., Ltd., China). The room temperature was controlled at 22 ± 1 °C in a sound proof room during the experiment. Before the experiment, the open field should be wiped clean with 75% alcohol to prevent other odors from affecting the locomotor activities of the mice. After the start of the experiment, the mice were first recorded for free exercise within 30 min to confirm the basic activities, and then, the movements of the mice within 150 min were recorded after s.c. injection of analogs 6 and 8 and the positive control fentanyl.

    Place Conditioning Experiment

    The experimental setup of the CPP consisted of three boxes: the two large boxes (20 × 20 × 20 cm) were separated by a small box (5 × 20 × 20 cm) as described previously, and separate groups of male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test.(20) At the bottom of two large plaids, a 5 × 5 cm small door was opened for mice to enter and exit, and the small door could be closed. One of the two large boxes was black, and another one was white. In addition, the two choice boxes were different in vision and tactile sensation (the white walls with a rough floor and the black walls with a smooth floor with 20 lux for blank and 50 lux for white).
    To eliminate the strain on the unfamiliar environment of the animals before the experiment, the mice were placed in a CPP box and adapted for 15 min without recording. On the preconditioning day (day 1) of the experiment, the mice were placed in a CPP device and allowed to move freely between the two boxes. Within 15 min of recording, mice spent more than 60% of the time in the same compartment were excluded from the tests. On the conditioning days (day 2–4) of drug treatment, the middle mortal door was closed. Animals were s.c. injected with drugs and placed in one of the choice boxes for 15 min in the morning. Then, mice were s.c. injected with saline approximately 6 h later and placed in the other box for 15 min. On the test day (postconditioning day, day 5), the middle door was opened, and the time that the mice stayed in the drug-associated preference box within 15 min was recorded.

    Nal-Precipitated Withdrawal Test

    According to previous studies,(62) the withdrawal response of mice to Nal pretreatment was evaluated and separate groups of male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test. Fentanyl and analogs 6 and 8 were s.c. injected every 8 h. The doses of the drugs were gradually increased. The reference was made to the dose of morphine (62, 124, 186, 248, 310, 310, and 310 mg/kg), and the dosage administered was about 10-, 20-, 30-, 40-, and 50-fold that of morphine antinociceptive ED50 (5.22 μmol/kg).(63) The ED50 value of fentanyl was 0.028 μmol/kg, and the dosage administered was 0.28, 0.56, 0.84, 1.12, 1.4, 1.4, and 1.4 μmol/kg. The ED50 values of analogs 6 and 8 were 0.003 and 0.002 μmol/kg, so the reference designs were gradually increasing the doses of injection (analog 6, 0.03, 0.06, 0.09, 0.12, 0.15, 0.15, and 0.15 μmol/kg; analog 8, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.1, 0.1, and 0.1 μmol/kg). Two hours after the last administration, 10 mg/kg Nal was s.c. injected, and the mice were immediately placed in an opaque barrel structure with an inner diameter of 9 cm and a height of 32 cm. The number of jumps of the mice within 30 min was recorded.

    GIT Test

    The upper gastrointestinal motility experiment was generally used to evaluate the side effect of opioids on constipation as described previously,(20) and separate groups of male Kunming mice (6–8 weeks old) were used for this test. The mice were fasted for 16 h but were free to drink water. The fasted mice were received s.c. injection of different doses of analogs 6 and 8 before an oral suspension. Then, each mouse was orally administered 250 μL of charcoal suspension (0.1 μL/10 g, a physiological saline suspension containing 5% charcoal and 10% gum arabic). After 30 min of oral gavage, mice were sacrificed by cervical dislocation. The mice were immediately dissected, and the small intestines were carefully removed from the stomach pylorus to the cecum. The results were expressed as the percent of GIT (GIT % = the distance travelled by the charcoal/the total distance of small intestine × 100).

    Data Analysis

    All data were expressed as means ± standard error of the mean (S.E.M.) from at least three separate experiments (n = 3) for in vitro test and at least 5 animals/group (n = 5) for in vivo test, where n = number of independent values. The EC50 values for the cAMP test or ED50 values for antinociceptive experiments and the corresponding 95% confidence limits were calculated with GraphPad Prism 5. Data obtained from our study, excluding the tolerance development test and CPP test, were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Dunnett’s or Bonferroni’s post-hoc test. Data from the tolerance development test were analyzed using one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s honestly significant difference (HSD) test. Data from the CPP test were analyzed using unpaired t-tests. The criterion of a probability of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
